title: New & Review: Prison Wine – Transmissions From The Saturnine Heart: Some Bedroom Recordings
body: I’m not convinced this is ‘new’ as such, more new to me I guess, yet I could find so little information about **Prison Wine**, that I’d hazard a guess that it’ll be fresh for most people. This collection of seven bedroom recordings recently uploaded to bandcamp, under the mysterious title ‘**_Transmissions From The Saturnine Heart: Some Bedroom Recordings_**‘, is a delicate, moving assortment of lo-fi folk tracks. The searingly poignant _Twist The Knife_, featuring the chilling line ‘_why are you keeping me alive? Go ahead and twist the knife_‘, is emotionally cutting in the straightest sense of the word. There’s a stunning sense of honesty and youthful forgiveness found throughout **_Transmissions From…_** such as the plea for understanding that is _Help Me_ (also the newest of the tracks) and the Americana inspired _Future Selves_. It’s somewhat perplexing as a release, with no tangible name or face to put to it, yet when the music is as engaging and expertly composed as **Prison Wine’s**, then the complete backstory is hardly needed. The full EP is available to download for free from the **Prison Wine** [bandcamp](http://prisonwine.bandcamp.com/album/transmissions-from-the-saturnine-heart-some-bedroom-recordings) page; stream _Twist The Knife_ below.
